channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Authorities say suspect in the Charlie Kirk shooting is in custody
item.description: Utah Gov. Spencer Cox opened a press briefing Friday morning by saying: "We got him." He named the suspect as Tyler Robinson and said he was turned in to authorities on Thursday night.

item.title: A look at the status of the FBI investigation into Charlie Kirk's killing
item.description: NPR speaks with Juliette Kayyem, Harvard lecturer and former Homeland Security assistant secretary, about the current status of the FBI investigation into Charlie Kirk's killing Wednesday.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The latest on the shooting death of Charlie Kirk, stock market soars despite worrying signals on jobs and consumer prices, Brazil's former President Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years for coup plot.

item.title: Rob Reiner and Michael McKean discuss 'Spinal Tap II: The End Continues'
item.description: NPR's A Martínez speaks with Rob Reiner and Michael McKean about "Spinal Tap II: The End Continues." The sequel comes more than 40 years after the original rock band mockumentary.

item.title: Jury trial of Ryan Routh, man accused of trying to kill Trump, begins in Florida
item.description: Testimony began Thursday in the trial of the man accused of attempting to assassinate Donald Trump last year on his Florida golf course. Ryan Routh faces up to life in prison if convicted.

item.title: Why mothers in the U.S. are scaling back on their work lives
item.description: Workforce participation for moms in the U.S. has been dropping for most of this year, and the reasons are more complicated than return-to-office mandates. The team from "The Indicator" explains why.

item.title: Typhus, a disease once nearly eradicated in the U.S., is on the rise in Texas
item.description: Texas is seeing an explosion of cases of typhus, a disease that – if untreated – can be fatal. Typhus was almost eradicated from the United States, but now it's making a comeback.

item.title: A look at the political fallout from the immigration raid at a Georgia Hyundai plant
item.description: After a mass immigration enforcement operation at a Georgia Hyundai plant, there are questions about how Republican-led states balance economic development with the president's immigration priorities.

item.title: Experts worry about possible increased political violence after Charlie Kirk murder
item.description: There's concern over the possibility that Charlie Kirk's killing may increase an already high level of political violence. Of particular concern is the language used by influencers and public figures.

item.title: A look at research on Americans' changing attitudes toward political violence
item.description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Robert Pape, a professor of political science at the University of Chicago, about Americans' changing attitudes toward political violence.
